title: Boy with cancer whose dream of owning dog helped him through chemo gets puppy
text:
13 year-old cancer survivor Johnny Martin dreamed of getting a dog to help him through over a year of treatment – and was thrilled when he was handed his own corgi puppy outside the hospital on Monday (Pictures: WGN9)

A young cancer sufferer whose dream of owning a dog helped him cope with treatment has been given an adorable corgi puppy.

Johnny Martin, 13, thought of his ideal corgi while undergoing chemotherapy at Lurie Children’s Hospital in Chicago five days a week for over a year.

He would gaze out the window of his treatment room at a nearby dog park, and focus on getting his own pet to take his mind of the grueling treatment he had to endure.

And on Monday, Johnny, who suffered from a rare soft cell cancer, was surprised with a beautiful black and white puppy while out for a walk after getting the all-clear.

The life-affirming moment was caught on camera by WGN9, with the puppy quickly taking to Johnny, and giving his friend’s face a lick to signal his approval.

Explaining the surprise, Lurie social worker Jessica King said: ‘It was all he wanted to talk about, so we knew we needed to get in touch with an organization that could fulfill that wish for him.’

King reached out to the Little Wish Foundation, which organizes puppies for animal lovers battling illnesses, with bosses there delighted to help.

Founder Liz Niemic explained: ‘I was 16 years old when I started Little Wish Foundation, and it was in memory of my friend Max, who battled kidney cancer.

‘Before Max passed away his last wish was to get a puppy. I never forgot what a big difference and impact it made on his life.’

Johnny suffered from a form of cancer so rare that Lurie had only treated one other patient suffering from it.

Johnny Martin suffered a cancer so rare his hospital had only treated one case of it previously. He underwent a 26 hour operation to remove all tumors from his body, and dreamed of dogs to get him through the grueling treatment (Picture: WGN9)

He underwent 26 hours of surgery to remove dozens of tumors growing in his chest cavity.

The inspirational youngster was declared cancer-free in September, but continues to undergo chemotherapy to ensure his tumors do not return.
description: Johnny Martin would gaze out the window at a nearby dog park to cheer himself up during a year of chemo...and this week he was finally surprised with his very own puppy
